I was aware of much of this, but Alexander's book argues that Wallis, far from being a champion of the usual proof-based approach to mathematics, was actively in favor of a purely inductive, experimental approach. For example, he calculates (what in today's language would be called) limits by computing a few examples and observing a trend. He declares that lines and triangles and so on actually exist, and so their nature can be observed, rather than just deduced. He was also a skilled politican, navigating the English civil war, academia, and the church. All in all, it is difficult to see him as the good guy in the conflict, even if Hobbes is undeniably the bad guy.Some observations, in reverse order of the outline above, follow. It is very bizarre to hear that there was once a time when mathematicians argued that you either proceeded by proof or you proceeded by examining examples; why one would sacrifice the certainty of proof or the intuition of computation is beyond me.A friend pointed out to me that Alexander basically argues that the Jesuits saved Catholicism. Said this bluntly, it is hard to swallow, no matter how corrupt the popes of that time were. It is a testament to Alexander's writing ability that he is able to imply this without it sounding outlandish.So much of Clavius's view of mathematics education sounds very similar to things you hear today. It is very striking to learn that the view that mathematics is a special science because it's results are eternal, and the view that math education is being harmed by inept teachers, and claims that all that's really needed for good math education are passionate, competent teachers that can make the student appreciate the subject's beauty, that these views are all centuries old. Alexander explicitly addresses some related ideas in a very interesting passage in Chapter 2.I was amused by some of the Catholic Church's banned theses in Chapter 4. One of them addressed whether there was a creation so perfect that God could not create a better one. This offers an intriguing answer to the old puzzle of whether God could create a stone so heavy he couldn't lift it. The answer is you aren't allowed to ask that question.Finally, regarding Alexander's dubious thesis, it is, even after finishing the book, hard to believe that the development of western civilization was dramatically altered by how it chose to answer the question of whether the line is composed of indivisible components. Nonetheless, he makes a strong case in the closing pages when he compares the cultural, economic, and mathematical fates of England and Italy.my favorite quote: "Today it is more likely to be teachers of philosophy and the humanities who complain that their fields are disrespected by instructors in the prestigious mathematical sciences."

The right place to begin a story, oftentimes, is in the middle. Amir Alexander apparently knows this, and at the beginning of Chapter 1, he takes us to a meeting in 1632 in Rome. Here, Jesuits from several nations gathered to consider, and pass judgement, on the idea that, mathematically speaking, we could consider lines and planes and such things to be composed of "indivisibles". By this was meant, infinitely small points.That the Jesuits decided that such a teaching was banned, is not so shocking. We all know that the Jesuits, and the Catholic Church generally, had a pretty poor record during large parts of the early Renaissance when it came to endorsing the latest science; Galileo's problems with the papacy are the stuff of legend. What is, though, to a modern read rather odd, is why the Church was even passing judgement on this. This was not the idea of the earth circling the sun, or that humans are descended from non-humans through the process of evolution. This is a mathematical, technical principle. It would take some time to explain to a typical believer what the principle at stake even was.But the Jesuits didn't just ban it. They banned it again and again, playing a game of whack-a-mole as it kept coming up in other contexts. Their opposition to the principle of the infinitesimal was implacable, unshakeable, and long-lasting. It is as if the evangelical Christians of today's America decided that Wiles' proof of Fermat's Last Theorem was the work of the devil, because it relies upon Iwasawa Theory. The response of the rest of us would not be to support or oppose their decision, but to wonder what in the world they were even talking about.Alexander spends the rest of the book explaining how the concept of the infinitesimal came to rest in the Jesuits' cross-hairs, and with it we learn about an event of fundamental importance in the history of the West. There was a time, when the greatest math, science, and philosophy came from Italy. Galileo was not a freak accident, he was the product of a culture and a society that produced many such minds. By the time he died, the flame was flickering, and by a generation after it had most assuredly passed northwards, to the lands of Copernicus, Kepler, Leibniz, and Newton.If you, like many of the people then or since, have little concern or interest in whether or not one may consider a line to be composed of an infinity of infinitely small points, you may wonder why you should read a book about it. The answer is that, while there is the occasional reference to math, that is not primarily what this book is about. This book is about what can cause a society, a culture, which has up until then been a center of learning and innovation, to lose that. The all-too-easy answer, based on both Renaissance Italy and the pre-Renaissance Islamic world (in its time also the center of math, philosopy, and scientific learning), is that it was religion.But, both the Islamic Golden Age and the Italian Renaissance took place in societies that were already deeply religious, so clearly that was not it. To explore how it came to be that the center of western European learning could fall, within a century, to an intellectual backwater, while the heretofore backwater of England could rise to intellectual supremacy, Alexander takes us through a story that defies summary.It is not beyond a good writer to tell the story, though, and Alexander is up to the task. By the time he finishes his tale, we are left with a melancholy sense of the rich intellectual ferment that was lost during Galileo's lifetime, but also a sense of how exciting it must have been to see it begin in London during Newton's. There is nothing inevitable about America's role as the place that the world's best scientists, engineers, and inventors go to develop their ideas. As the current world center of scientific and technological innovation, we in America would do well to see how those who were on top before us, have fallen.
